description.text: The Goal: Though growth and stability in banking are improving, it’s still a problem that hinders growth. A well-funded, reliable, and self-sufficient financial sector that will remove constraints on growth, reduce barriers to entrepreneurship, and improve infrastructure. Simple and reliable money movement builds economies.

The Problem: According to the International Monetary Fund, “financial sectors in low-income sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) are among the world's least developed” and under-funded. This creates constraints in policy making, hinders efforts to alleviate poverty, and restricts growth in other key infrastructure goals.
The financial services sector needs to:

→ Bulk up assets. The assets held by most low-income African countries are smaller than those controlled and held by a “single medium-sized bank” in more industrialized nations. Without accessible/liquid assets, the sector is vulnerable and more conservative with (or intolerant to) investments. (Source)
→ Increase the percentage of banked population. 350 million (of an estimated 950 million) sub-Saharan Africans are unbanked. Lack of funds is the first-cited reason for remaining unbanked. Distance to a financial institution is cited as the second-biggest reason for those who remain unbanked. (Source)
→ Improve stability and trust. There is a large portion of the population that doesn’t trust financial institutions due to a memorable history of bank failures and currency devaluations.

information.text: Sub-Saharan Africa is home to several of the fastest-growing economies. 5 countries were ahead of China in growth as of 2012, and 22 were ahead of India. (Source)
Of the 38% percent of the global unbanked population, 17% of that total lives in sub-Saharan Africa (which amounts to roughly 350 million people in the region). (Source)

The average annual growth of regional GDP in sub-Saharan Africa was 5.25% in 2012 (post-financial crisis) showing resilience and growth that outpaced most developing countries in the same time period. (Source)

description.text: The Goal: According to the World Bank, “the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) aim to achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water and sanitation for all by 2030.”

The Problem: Though access to piped water increased between 2000 and 2015, the population grew even faster, leading to a decrease in the percentage of homes with access to piped water (from 40% to 33%) (Source).
To meet SDG, the utilities need to:

→ Improve access and user adoption. Without consistency of experience and supply reliability, it’s hard to convince homes to invest in piping. This, in turn, further erodes the water utility’s profits and hinders further investment in infrastructure. 
→ Balancing customer and supplier needs. There needs to be a balance between the goals of revenue sufficiency, access, usage, and affordability.
→ Improve wastewater collection and treatment. Few of the facilities  available today provide this service.
→ Increase the pace of development. Today, the facility development pace is underperforming when compared to the pace at which the population is growing. Significant investment is needed to close the gap.

Between 2000-2015, the urban population of Africa increased by over 80% according to the World Bank utility report. Advancements made in water infrastructure need to outpace population growth for reliable coverage.

description.text: The Goal: The population and its urban density are exploding in sub-Saharan Africa. The goal is to prove the attractiveness of the local real estate markets, which is a direct result of investment in the other sectors. According to RICS.org, the strength of real estate is directly tied to the strength of “institutions operating in the market, the ability to improve market transparency as well as developing the types of skills that can respond to  growing market demand and the professional skills gap of the country.”

The Problem: According to the same sources, “Currently, the lack of available and reliable data and research has resulted in the perception that African property markets, like other developing markets, are too high in risk to justify the potential rewards.”
The real estate sector needs to:

→ Improve transparency. The perception of investment quality is directly linked to the availability and reliability of market data.
→ Find creative financing. Global real estate markets are usually propped up by local bank mortgage lending. There needs to be greater mortgage financing availability, which may more easily come from outside of the banking sector.
→ Improve stability and trust. Perceptions are powerful investment markers, and there is a sense of risk that prevents investors from diving into the market. The sector needs to improve trust with the local and global populations to attract investors.

description.text: The Goal: To improve waste management, collection, and disposal of waste at a pace that’s sustainable with population growth.

"Extending regular and reliable waste collection services to all. Safe disposal of residual waste to sanitary engineered landfills, while maximizing the recovery of secondary resources from these waste streams through social and technological innovations appropriate for Africa.” - Africa Waste Management Outlook

The Problem: 125 million tons of municipal solid waste (MSW) were generated in Africa in 2012 (the most recently reported year), which was expected to double by 2025. Only 55% of that waste gets collected by a collection service, and over 90% of the waste generated in Africa gets disposed of through uncontrolled dumpsites and landfills. The population (and associated waste) is set to grow so rapidly that it has the potential to negate any improvement made in another country. (Source)

The waste management sector needs to:
→ Look for unexpected opportunities. Waste can be a resource. Diverting waste away from the uncontrolled dumpsites and landfills towards reuse and recovery could add an annual US$8 billion into the African economy. (Source)
→ Bring it under control. There needs to be simultaneous improvements in collection and disposal practices (move away from burning, reduce commercial waste, improve sanitation practices, etc.)

description.text: The Goal: The African Telecommunication Union’s secretary-general John Amo states that an investment in fiber technology is needed to keep Africa competitive and attractive on the global stage, or else find itself further left behind.

The Problem: “Limited broadband, inevitably leads to limited industrial progression, inefficient trade and information sharing. That leads directly to a disadvantageous place for Africa on the global trade, political and other fabric of the ecosystem - whether it be political, economic or social.” - John Amo
The telecoms sector needs to:

→ Invest in broadband infrastructure. Private sector investments tend to scale more efficiently and roll out more effectively. For every 10% increase in broadband penetration, GDP sees a boost of 1.38% (Source).
→ Work with government. While private sector investment is needed, for connectivity to work, governments need to lay the fertile groundwork through a broadband development strategy, fiscal strategy to encourage investment, and improved youth education programs to build out local IT skillsets. (Source)
→ Collaborate across the diaspora. Telecoms has seen a sharp increase in user adoption over the last few years. Paired with an exploding population, the opportunities are endless. But considering only state sovereignty will limit the effectiveness of the sector. (Source)

description.text: The Goal: Stable, affordable, and profitable electrification across sub-Saharan Africa. According to recent research, based on the current pace of population growth and the current rate of electrification, the region will not have full electricity access until 2080.

The Problem: According to OxFam, sub-Saharan Africa is the most electricity-poor region in the world. In most of the countries in the region, ⅔ of the population does not have access to modern energy/utility services.
To address this problem, utilities need to:

→ Expand generation capacity. The existing infrastructure often doesn’t have enough supply to deliver consistent energy to the existing grid-connected regions.
→ Reduce service disruptions. Additionally, the regions connected to the grid may not get consistent access to power because of poor power transmission procedures.
→ Reduce the cost differential. Power has inconsistent pricing, which furthers the divide between classes. As such, when paired with inconsistent generation/delivery, expensive on-site self-generation has grown in industrial, commercial, and residential sectors. This reduces the reliability of profits for energy producers, further hindering development.
→ Focus internally. The grid, as it’s built, will enter the market with access to more efficient appliances and systems than more developed nations had. Instead of looking to how other countries have built their grid, sub-Saharan Africa will need to define its own path.

description.text: The Goal: To create a self-sufficient food system with a clear path to eliminating hunger in sub-Saharan Africa.

The Problem: According to the International Labour Organization report (published in 2017), the agricultural sector employs an average of 54% of the working-age population in Africa. Despite the huge potential (sub-Saharan Africa boasts the highest area of arable uncultivated land in the world), around one quarter of the population experiences hunger. (Source)
To meet goals in the region, the agriculture sector needs to:

→ Produce more food. The continent is currently a net importer of food, which puts a strain on foreign exchange reserves. There are significant climate change and public funding-related hurdles standing in the way of profitable production. (Source)
→ Address food storage problems. Many unnecessary agricultural losses stem from poor conservation techniques or post-harvest losses due to inadequate storage.
→ Improve access to information. Storm patterns and local agricultural disease information does not always make it to farmers, leaving them more vulnerable and underprepared.
→ Unequal access for female farmers. Funding, land transfer rights, and rules governing ownership to land discriminate against women. (Source)
→ Lack of irrigation. Sub-Saharan Africa relies heavily on rainfall. There is low usage of irrigation systems which makes food supplies much more vulnerable to the elements. (Source)

description.text: The Goal: The effectiveness of local logistics is a significant contributor to a region’s economic prospects. The African continent is becoming a more important trading bloc, especially for Asia and parts of Europe. There are vast resources, growing wealth, a growing population, and a larger middle class with loftier purchasing power in the region.
The goal is to release enhanced tracking systems, improve and digitize the flow of information, and improve artificial intelligence and automation to improve trade.

The Problem: “The big global logistics companies are too expensive for African firms, and that’s one of the reasons that basic goods, even diapers and soap, aren’t available to consumers,” Obi Ozor, CEO and co-founder of Kobo360.

Sub-Saharan African economies are majorly export- and commodity-dependent. They currently wrestle with insufficient policy frameworks, huge infrastructure gaps, and barriers to trade leading to a supply chain that is largely broken.
The logistics sector needs to:

→ Focus on infrastructure investments. Things that make logistics work include lit roads to see at night, address systems that link communities and land to the greater grid, and improved mobile connectivity to provide tracking and information, etc. (Source)
→ Reduce government-imposed hurdles. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) is an example of a group dedicated to this cause. They have set a goal to reduce tariffs on 90% of all goods to allow for the free movement of goods, services, capital, and people. (Source)
→ Improve service and communication. Logistics companies need to work with the AfCFTA and focus on “reducing transport costs and delays, and improving the quality of service along transport corridors” according to Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa
→ Invest in education. As the tech ecosystem expands, the local skillset to support it needs to follow suit. (Source)

Sub-Saharan African economies are majorly export- and commodity-dependent. They currently wrestle with insufficient policy frameworks, huge infrastructure gaps, and barriers to trade leading to a supply chain that is largely broken.
The logistics sector needs to:

→ Focus on infrastructure investments. Things that make logistics work include lit roads to see at night, address systems that link communities and land to the greater grid, and improved mobile connectivity to provide tracking and information, etc. (Source)
→ Reduce government-imposed hurdles. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) is an example of a group dedicated to this cause. They have set a goal to reduce tariffs on 90% of all goods to allow for the free movement of goods, services, capital, and people. (Source)
→ Improve service and communication. Logistics companies need to work with the AfCFTA and focus on “reducing transport costs and delays, and improving the quality of service along transport corridors” according to Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa
→ Invest in education. As the tech ecosystem expands, the local skillset to support it needs to follow suit. (Source)

content.text: Jawudi, Inc. a Delaware corporation, is serious about protecting your privacy. This Privacy Policy (“Policy”) covers how Remitly collects and uses the personal information you provide on our website and in conjunction with any of the services hosted at [www.jawudi.com) (“Service” and “Website”), including money transfer services accessed by internet enabled devices.

It also describes the choices available to you regarding our use of your personal information and how you can access and update this information. This Policy also applies if you participate in our research projects.
The Policy was last updated on January 4, 2021.

This Policy explains what personal information we collect about you, with whom we share it, and how you can elect in certain situations to not share information with third parties. “Personal Information” refers to information such as name and email that can be used to identify you individually.

We may amend this Policy at any time, and whenever we do so we will notify you by posting a revised version on the Website. If, however, we plan to make a material change in the way we collect, use, or store your personal information, we will provide prior notice on our website, and by email.

You will then have the chance to decide whether or not we will use or disclose your information in that new manner, whether through an “opt-out” procedure or by ending your relationship with us. Such changes will become effective, at the earliest, 30 days after the date of the email notifications.
We ask that minors refrain from using our Service or submitting any personal information to us.
Minors (those under the age of 18 years) are not eligible to use our Service.
If you have questions or concerns regarding this Policy, you should contact us.
Information We Collect
We will collect the following information about you, which may include non-public personal information:

1. Personal and financial Information you give us as a result of using the Service, such as your address, e-mail address, date of birth, telephone number, all or part of your Social Security number, bank account online login information, bank account number, and credit/debit card number. Under certain circumstances we will also collect and save information obtained from (i) copies of official identification documents, including your Passport or Drivers' License, and (ii) your picture, video/ audio recording, or other evidence of yourself with your identification documentation.

2. Third party personal information you provide in order for us to facilitate funds transfers, such as your recipient's full name, physical address, email address, and phone number. However, we will not contact your recipients except as instructed by you or as required to complete a transaction. This information is only used for the sole purpose of completing your request or for whatever reason it may have been provided.
3. Information about your usage of the Service, including your transaction history, and how and to whom you use the Service to send or receive money;
4. Information that we lawfully obtain from third parties, such as identity verification services, electronic database services, and credit reporting agencies;

5. Information that we indirectly obtain from you, such as information about the hardware and software you use when accessing the Service, your IP address, and the pages you access on this website, and other websites that you visit prior to accessing the Service.
Continued.....

1. The Service
We recommend you use the Service to send money to friends and family and, therefore, you should not use the Service to send money to strangers.

The Service allows users to send international money transfers from the United States to other countries served by Remitly. A “Sender” uses the Service to send money and a “Recipient” receives money through the Service. A “Transaction” refers to an order to send money through the Service. The “Transaction Amount” is the amount in US dollars that the Sender provides to Remitly for transmittal to the Recipient. The “Payout Amount” is the amount paid out to the Recipient.
